Knowledge Point: The enclitics \phono{-pis}, \phono{-taq}, and \phono{-raq} can all be used to coordinate NPs~(\ref{Glo7:Walmi}--\ref{Glo7:Uyqapaq}), AdvPs and VPs~(\ref{Glo7:Ishpani}); the case suffix \phono{-wan} can be used with the first two of these three~(\ref{Glo7:Mila}). \phono{-pis}, \phono{-taq}, and \phono{-raq} generally imply relations of inclusion, contrast, or contradiction, respectively. Thus, \phono{-pis} (inclusion) can generally be translated as ‘and’ or ‘also’~(\ref{Glo7:Walmi}),~(\ref{Glo7:Uyqapaq}).
Content 1: \gsrc walmi\textbf{pis} qali\textbf{pis} | \gll walmi-pis qali-pis | \gls woman-ADD man-ADD | \glt women \textbf{and} men\protect\footnotemark[1]
Content 2: \gsrc Uyqapaq\textbf{pis} kanmi alpakapaq\textbf{pis} kanmi llamapaq\textbf{pis} kanmi. | \gll uyqa-paq-pis ka-n-mi alpaka-paq-pis ka-n-mi llama-paq-pis ka-n-mi | \gls sheep-ABL-ADD be-3-EVD alpaca-ABL-ADD be-3-EVD llama-ABL-ADD be--3--EVD | \glt There are [some] out of sheep [wool] \textbf{and} there are [some] out of alpaca [wool] \textbf{and} there are [some] out of llama [wool].
Content 3: \gsrc Ishpani\textbf{pis}chu puquchini\textbf{pis}chu. | \gll ishpa-ni-pis-chu puqu-chi-ni-pis-chu | \gls urinate-1-ADD-NEG ferment-CAUS-1-ADD-NEG | \glt I \textbf{neither} urinate \textbf{nor} ferment [urine].
Content 4: \gsrc Mila\textbf{wan} Alicia\textbf{wan} Hilda trayaramun.~\updag | \gll Mila-wan Alicia-wan Hilda traya-ra-mu-n | \gls Mila-INSTR Alicia-INSTR Hilda-INSTR arrive-URGT-CISL-3 | \glt Hilda arrived with Mila \textbf{and} Alicia.
Content 5: \gsrc walmi\textbf{pis} qali\textbf{pis} | \gll walmi-pis qali-pis | \gls woman-ADD man-ADD | \glt women \textbf{and} men\protect\footnotemark[1]
Content 6: \gsrc Uyqapaq\textbf{pis} kanmi alpakapaq\textbf{pis} kanmi llamapaq\textbf{pis} kanmi. | \gll uyqa-paq-pis ka-n-mi alpaka-paq-pis ka-n-mi llama-paq-pis ka-n-mi | \gls sheep-ABL-ADD be-3-EVD alpaca-ABL-ADD be-3-EVD llama-ABL-ADD be--3--EVD | \glt There are [some] out of sheep [wool] \textbf{and} there are [some] out of alpaca [wool] \textbf{and} there are [some] out of llama [wool].

Knowledge Point: \phono{-wan} is unmarked and can generally be translated as ‘and’~(\ref{Glo7:Mila}).
Content 1: \gsrc Mila\textbf{wan} Alicia\textbf{wan} Hilda trayaramun.~\updag | \gll Mila-wan Alicia-wan Hilda traya-ra-mu-n | \gls Mila-INSTR Alicia-INSTR Hilda-INSTR arrive-URGT-CISL-3 | \glt Hilda arrived with Mila \textbf{and} Alicia.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-taq} and \phono{-raq} (contrast and contradiction) can both be translated ‘but’, ‘while’, ‘whereas’ and so on~(\ref{Glo7:Wawanchikta}).
Content 1: \gsrc Wawanchikta idukanchik qillakunaqa mana\textbf{taq}mi. | \gll wawa-nchik-ta iduka-nchik qilla-kuna-qa mana-taq-mi | \gls baby-1PL-ACC educate-1PL lazy-PL-TOP no-SEQ-EVD | \glt We’re educating our children; \textbf{whereas} the lazy ones aren’t.

Knowledge Point: Additional strategies employed for coordination in \SYQ{} include (a)~the employment of the indigenous coordinating particle \phono{icha} ‘or’~(\ref{Glo7:Mikuramanmantri}) or any of the borrowed Spanish coordinators \phono{i} ‘and’~(\ref{Glo7:Tushunchik}), \phono{u} ‘or’~(\ref{Glo7:Kaytaq}), \phono{piru} ‘but’~(\ref{Glo7:turiypis}), or \phono{ni} ‘nor’~(\ref{Glo7:alpaka}) (\Sp~\spanish{y}, \spanish{o}, \spanish{pero}, and \spanish{ni}) and (b)~juxtaposition.
Content 1: \gsrc Mikuramanmantri kara \textbf{icha} aparamanmantri. | \gll miku-ra-ma-n-man-tri ka-ra icha apa-ra-ma-n-man-tri | \gls eat-URGT-1.OBJ-3-COND-EVC be-PST or bring-URGT-1.OBJ-3-COND-EVC | \glt It would have eaten me \textbf{or} it would have taken me away.
Content 2: \gsrc Tushunchik i imahintam kriyinchik ñuqakunaqa \textbf{piru} chay ivanhilyukuna sabadistakunaqa mana kriyinchu. | \gll tushu-nchik i imahin-ta-m kriyi-nchik ñuqa-kuna-qa piru chay ivanhilyu-kuna sabadista-kuna-qa mana kriyi-n-chu | \gls dance-1PL and image-ACC-EVD believe-1PL 1-PL-TOP but DEM.D Evangelical-PL Seventh.Day.Adventist-PL-TOP no believe-3-NEG | \glt We dance and believe in the saints \textbf{but} those Evangelists and Seventh Day Adventists don’t believe.
Content 3: \gsrc Kaytaq ishkay puntraw \textbf{u} huk puntrawllam ruwa:. | \gll kay-taq ishkay puntraw u huk puntraw-lla-m ruwa-: | \gls DEM.P-SEQ two day or one day-RSTR-EVD make-1 | \glt I make this one in two days \textbf{or} just one day.
Content 5: \gsrc \textbf{Ni} alpaka \textbf{ni} llama. Kanan manam trayamun\textbf{chu}. | \gll ni alpaka ni llama kanan mana-m traya-mu-n-chu | \gls nor alpaca nor llama now no-EVD arrive-CISL-3-NEG | \glt \textbf{Neither} alpacas \textbf{nor} llamas. They don’t come here now.

Knowledge Point: Juxtaposition is accomplished with the placement of the coordinated elements in sequence~(\ref{Glo7:Sibadakunata}), (\ref{Glo7:Walmiqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Sibadakunata kargashpa, triguta rantishpa, sarata rantishpam purira. | \gll sibada-kuna-ta karga-shpa trigu-ta ranti-shpa sara-ta ranti-shpa-m puri-ra | \gls barley-PL-ACC carry-SUBIS wheat-ACC buy-SUBIS corn-ACC buy-SUBIS-EVD walk-PST | \glt They walked about, carrying barley and selling wheat \textbf{and} selling corn.
Content 2: \gsrc Walmiqa talpunchik, allichanchikmi. | \gll walmi-qa talpu-nchik alli-cha-nchik-mi | \gls woman-TOP plant-1PL good-FACT-1PL-EVD | \glt We women plant \textbf{and} fix up [the soil].

Knowledge Point: When \phono{-kuna} signals inclusion, it can be used to coordinate NP’s~(\ref{Glo7:Chayman}) (see~\sectref{sssc:nonex}).
Content 1: \gsrc Chayman risa Marleni, Ayde, Vilma, Norma\textbf{kuna}. | \gll chay-man ri-sa Marleni Ayde Vilma Norma-kuna | \gls DEM.D-ALL go-NPST Marleni Ayde Vilma Norma-PL | \glt Marleni went there with Ayde, Vilma \textbf{and} Norma.

Knowledge Point: The Spanish coordinators are widely employed. Coordinators indigenous to \SYQ{} generally attach to both coordinated elements~(\ref{Glo7:Ullqush}). The coordinators are not necessarily mutually exclusive.
Content 1: \gsrc Ullqush\textbf{pis} kayan, ¿aw? Chuqlluqupa\textbf{pis} yuraq\textbf{pis} puka\textbf{pis}. | \gll ullqush-pis ka-ya-n aw chuqlluqupa-pis yuraq-pis puka-pis | \gls ullqush.flowers-ADD be-PROG-3 yes chuqlluqupa.flowers-ADD white-ADD red-ADD | \glt There are \phono{ullqush} flowers, \textbf{too}, no? \phono{Chuqlluqupa} flowers, \textbf{too} -- white and red.

Knowledge Point: Comparisons of inequality are formed in \SYQ{} with the borrowed particle \phono{mas} (‘more’) in construction with the indigenous ablative case suffix, \phono{-paq}, which attaches to the base of comparison~(\ref{Glo7:Huancayopaqa}), (\ref{Glo7:Qaynapuntraw}).
Content 1: \gsrc Huancayopaqa wak mashwaqa papa\textbf{paq}pis \textbf{mas}mi kwistan. | \gll \iliHuancayo}-pa-qa wak mashwa-qa papa-paq-pis mas-mi kwista-n | \gls \ili{Huancayo-LOC-TOP DEM.D mashua-TOP potato-ABL-ADD more-EVD cost-3 | \glt In \ili{Huancayo}, mashua costs \textbf{more} than potatoes.
Content 2: \gsrc Qayna puntraw\textbf{paq} \textbf{mas}mi. | \gll qayna puntraw-paq mas-mi | \gls previous day-ABL more-EVD | \glt It’s \textbf{more} than yesterday.

Knowledge Point: \phono{mas} and \phono{minus} ‘less’, also borrowed from Spanish, may function as pronouns~(\ref{Glo7:Granadakunaktapis}) and adjectives~(\ref{Glo7:Qaynawata}), and, when inflected with accusative \phono{-ta}, as adverbs~(\ref{Glo7:Masta}) as well.
Content 1: \gsrc Granadakunaktapis, armamintukunaktapis lantiyan \textbf{mas}ta. | \gll granada-kuna-kta-pis armamintu-kuna-kta-pis lanti-ya-n mas-ta | \gls grenade-PL-ACC-ADD armaments-PL-ACC-ADD buy-PROG-3 more-ACC | \glt Grenades and weapons and all, too -- they’re buying \textbf{more}.
Content 2: \gsrc Qayna wata pukum karqa. Chaymi \textbf{minus} pastupis karqa. | \gll qayna wata puku-m ka-rqa chay-mi minus pastu-pis ka-rqa | \gls previous year little-EVD be-PST DEM.D-EVD less pasture.grass-ADD be-PST | \glt Last year there was little [rain]. So there was \textbf{less} pasture grass.
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Masta}qa mashtakuyanmi. | \gll mas-ta-qa mashta-ku-ya-n-mi | \gls more-ACC-TOP spread-REFL-PROG-3-EVD | \glt It’s spreading out \textbf{more}.

Knowledge Point: Also borrowed from Spanish are the irregular \phono{mihur} ‘better’~(\ref{Glo7:Pular}) and \phono{piyur} ‘worse’ (\ref{Glo7:Unayqamana}), (\ref{Glo7:Sapa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Pular\textbf{paq}pis \textbf{mas} \textbf{mihur}tam chayqa ayllukun. | \gll pular-paq-pis mas mihur-ta-m chay-qa ayllu-ku-n | \gls fleece-ABL-ADD more better-ACC-EVD DEM.D-TOP wrap-REFL-3 | \glt It’s \textbf{much better} than fleece -- this wraps [you] up.
Content 2: \gsrc Unayqa manayá iskwilaqa kasa. Unayqa analfabitullaya kayaq. Warmiqa \textbf{piyur}. | \gll unay-qa mana-yá iskwila-qa ka-sa unay-qa analfabitu-lla-ya ka-ya-q warmi-qa piyur | \gls before-TOP no-EMPH school-TOP be-NPST before-TOP illiterate-RSTR-EMO be-PROG-AG woman-TOP worse | \glt Ah, before, they didn’t have schools. Before, they were just illiterate. \textbf{Worse} [for the] women.
Content 3: \gsrc Sapa putraw \textbf{piyur piyur}ñam kayani. Mastaña qayna puntraw mana puriyta wakchawta qatiyta atipanichu. | \gll sapa putraw piyur piyur-ña-m ka-ya-ni mas-ta-ña qayna puntraw mana puri-y-ta wakchaw-ta qati-y-ta atipa-ni-chu | \gls every day worse worse-DISC-EVD be-PROG-1 more-ACC-DISC previous day no walk-INF-ACC sheep-ACC follow-INF-ACC be.able-1-NEG | \glt Every day it’s worse, I’m worse. More yesterday. I couldn’t walk or take out my sheep.

Knowledge Point: Comparisons of equality are formed with the borrowed particle \phono{igwal} ‘equal’, ‘same’ in construction with the indigenous instrumental/comitative case suffix, \phono{-wan}, which attaches to the base of comparison~(\ref{Glo7:Runa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Runa\textbf{wan} \textbf{igwal}triki vakaqa: nuybi mis. | \gll runa-wan igwal-tr-iki vaka-qa: nuybi mis | \gls person-INSTR equal-EVC-IKI cow-TOP nine month | \glt Cows are the \textbf{same} as people: [they gestate for] nine months.

Knowledge Point: This section partially repeats \sectref{ssec:innedi} on \phono{-chu}. Please consult that section for further discussion and glossed examples. In \SYQ, negation\index[sub]{negation} is indicated by the enclitic \phono{-chu} in combination with any of the particles \phono{mana}, \phono{ama}, or \phono{ni} or with the enclitic suffix \phono{-pis}. \phono{-chu} attaches to the sentence fragment that is the focus of negation. In negative sentences, \phono{-chu} generally co-occurs with \phono{mana} ‘not’~(\ref{Glo7:Chaytri}),~(\ref{Glo7:Aa}). \phono{-chu} is also licensed by additive \phono{-pis}~(\ref{Glo7:Kaspin}),~(\ref{Glo7:Manchakushpa}) as well as by \phono{ni} ‘nor’~(\ref{Glo7:Apuraw}),~(\ref{Glo7:Manamwayta}).
Content 1: \gsrc Chaytri \textbf{mana} suyawarqa\textbf{chu}. | \gll chay-tri mana suya-wa-rqa-chu | \gls DEM.D-EVC no wait-1.OBJ-PST-NEG | \glt That’s why she would\textbf{n’t} have waited for me.
Content 2: \gsrc Aa, \textbf{mana}ya kan\textbf{chu}. \textbf{Mana}ya bulayuq kan\textbf{chu}. | \gll aa mana-ya ka-n-chu mana-ya bula-yuq ka-n-chu | \gls ah no-EMO be-3-NEG no-EMO ball-POSS be-3-NEG | \glt Ah, there are\textbf{n’t} any. \textbf{No one} has any balls.
Content 3: \gsrc Kaspin\textbf{pis} kan\textbf{chu}. | \gll kaspi-n-pis ka-n-chu | \gls stick-3-ADD be-3-NEG | \glt She \textbf{doesn’t} have a stick.
Content 4: \gsrc Manchakushpa tuta\textbf{s} puñu:\textbf{chu}. | \gll mancha-ku-shpa tuta-s puñu-:-chu | \gls scare-REFL-SUBIS night-ADD sleep-1-NEG | \glt Being scared, I \textbf{didn’t} sleep at night.
Content 5: \gsrc Apuraw wañururqariki. \textbf{Ni} apanña\textbf{chu}. | \gll apuraw wañu-ru-rqa-r-iki ni apa-n-ña-chu | \gls quick die-URGT-PST-R-IKI nor bring-3-DISC-NEG | \glt He died quickly. They \textbf{didn’t even} bring him [to the hospital].
Content 6: \gsrc \textbf{Manam} wayta\textbf{chu} \textbf{ni} pishqu\textbf{chu}. | \gll manam wayta-chu ni pishqu-chu | \gls no-EVD flower-NEG nor bird-NEG | \glt \textbf{Neither} a flower \textbf{nor} a bird.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-chu} co-occurs with \phono{ama} in prohibitions~(\ref{Glo7:Ama}) and imperatives~(\ref{Glo7:kutimu}), (\ref{Glo7:nunka}), as well as in injunctions~(\ref{Glo7:chun}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¡\textbf{Ama} manchariy\textbf{chu}! ¡\textbf{Ama} qaway\textbf{chu}! | \gll ama mancha-ri-y-chu ama qawa-y-chu | \gls PROH scare-INCEP-IMP-NEG AMA look-IMP-CHU | \glt \textbf{Don’t} be scared! \textbf{Don’t} look!
Content 2: \gsrc ¡\textbf{Ama} kutimu\textbf{nki}\textbf{chu}! Qamqa isturbum kayanki. | \gll ama kuti-mu-nki-chu qam-qa isturbu-m ka-ya-nki | \gls PROH return-CISL-2-NEG you-TOP nuisance-EVD be-PROG-2 | \glt \textbf{Don’t} you come back! You’re a hinderance.
Content 3: \gsrc ¡\textbf{Ama}m nunka katraykanaku\textbf{shun}\textbf{chu}! | \gll ama-m nunka katra-yka-naku-shun-chu | \gls PROH-EVD never release-EXCEP-RECIP-1PL.FUT-NEG | \glt \textbf{Let’s never} leave each other!
Content 4: \gsrc ¡\textbf{Ama} wañu\textbf{chun}\textbf{chu}!~\updag | \gll ama wañu-chun-chu | \gls PROH die-INJUNC-NEG | \glt \textbf{Don’t let} her die!

Knowledge Point: \phono{-chu} does not appear in subordinate clauses. In subordinate clauses negation is indicated with a negative particle alone~(\ref{Glo7:kaptinqa}--\ref{Glo7:qatrachakunanpaq}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mana} qali kaptinqa ñuqanchikpis taqllakta hapishpa qaluwanchik. | \gll mana qali ka-pti-n-qa ñuqanchik-pis taqlla-kta hapi-shpa qaluwa-nchik | \gls no man be-SUBDS-3-TOP we-ADD plow-ACC grab-SUBIS turn.earth-1PL | \glt When there are \textbf{no} men, we grab the plow and turn the earth.
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Mana} qatrachakunanpaq mandilchanta watachakun. | \gll mana qatra-cha-ku-na-n-paq mandil-cha-n-ta wata-cha-ku-n | \gls no dirty-FACT-REFL-NMLZ-3-PURP apron-DIM-3-ACC tie-DIM-REFL-3 | \glt She’s tying on her apron \textbf{so} she does\textbf{n’t} get dirty.

Knowledge Point: Absolute~(\ref{Glo7:Chuqamunkiman}) and disjunctive~(\ref{Glo7:Maytaq}), ~(\ref{Glo7:Maniyayan}) questions are formed with the enclitic \phono{-chu}. When it functions to indicate interrogation\index[sub]{interrogation}, \phono{-chu} attaches to the sentence fragment that is the focus of the interrogation~(\ref{Glo7:Chaypa}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Chuqamunkiman\textbf{chu}? | \gll chuqa-mu-nki-man-chu | \gls throw-CISL-2-COND-Q | \glt Can you throw?
Content 2: \gsrc ¿Maytaq chayqa? ¿Apurí\textbf{chu} Viñac\textbf{chu}? | \gll may-taq chay-qa Apurí-chu Viñac-chu | \gls where-SEQ DEM.D-TOP Apurí-Q Viñac-Q | \glt Where is that? Apurí \textbf{or} Viñac?
Content 3: \gsrc ¿Maniyayan \textbf{icha} katrariyan\textbf{chu}? | \gll maniya-ya-n icha katra-ri-ya-n-chu | \gls tie.limbs-PROG-3 or release-INCEP-PROG-3-NEG | \glt Is she tying its feet \textbf{or} is she setting it loose?
Content 4: \gsrc ¿Chaypa\textbf{chu} tumarqanki? | \gll chay-pa-chu tuma-rqa-nki | \gls DEM.D-LOC-Q take-PST-2 | \glt Did you take [pictures] there?

Knowledge Point: In disjunctive questions, it generally attaches to each of the disjuncts~(\ref{Glo7:Kanastapi}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Kanastapi\textbf{chu} baldipi\textbf{chu}? | \gll kanasta-pi-chu baldi-pi-chu | \gls basket-LOC-Q bucket-LOC-Q | \glt In the basket \textbf{or} in the bucket?

Knowledge Point: Questions that anticipate a negative answer are indicated by \phono{manachu}~(\ref{Glo7:Manachu}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿\textbf{Manachu} friqulniki? ¿Puchukarun\textbf{chu}? | \gll mana-chu friqul-ni-ki puchuka-ru-n-chu | \gls no-Q bean-EUPH-2 finish-URGT-3-Q | \glt Do\textbf{n’t} you have any beans? They’re finished?

Knowledge Point: \phono{Manachu} may also “soften” questions~(\ref{Glo7:wankuchata}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿\textbf{Manachu} chay wankuchata qawanki? | \gll mana-chu chay wanku-cha-ta qawa-nki | \gls no-Q DEM.D mold-DIM-ACC see-2 | \glt You have\textbf{n’t} seen the little [cheese] mold?

Knowledge Point: \phono{Manachu}, like \phono{aw} ‘yes’, may also be used in the formation of tag questions~(\ref{Glo7:chimpapaqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Wak chimpapaqa yuraqyayan, ¿\textbf{manachu}? | \gll wak chimpa-pa-qa yuraq-ya-ya-n mana-chu | \gls DEM.D front-LOC-TOP white-INCH-PROG-3 no-Q | \glt There in front they’re turning white, \textbf{aren’t they}?

Knowledge Point: Interrogative \phono{-chu} does not appear in questions using interrogative pronouns~(\ref{Glo7:haqtrirqa}), (\ref{Glo7:Pitaq}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Constituent questions are formed with the interrogative-indefinite stems \phono{pi} ‘who’, \phono{ima} ‘what’, \phono{imay} ‘when’, \phono{may} ‘where’, \phono{imayna} ‘how’, \phono{mayqin} ‘which’, \phono{imapaq} ‘why’, and \phono{ayka} ‘how much/many’ (see~Table~\ref{Tab9}). Interrogative pronouns are formed by suffixing the stem --~generally but not obligatorily~-- with one of the enclitics \phono{-taq}, \phono{-raq}, \phono{-mI}, \phono{-shI} or \phono{-trI}~(\ref{Glo7:uraraq}--\ref{Glo7:Tapun}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc ¿\textbf{Imay uraraq} chay kunihuqa kutimunqa yanapamananpaq? | \gll imay ura-raq chay kunihu-qa kuti-mu-nqa yanapa-ma-na-n-paq | \gls when hour-CONT DEM.D rabbit-TOP return-CISL-3.FUT help-1.OBJ-NMLZ-3-PURP | \glt \textbf{What time} is that rabbit going to come back so he can help me?
Content 3: \gsrc Tapun, “¿\textbf{Imapaq} waqakunki, paluma?” | \gll tapu-n ima-paq waqa-ku-nki paluma | \gls ask-3 what-PURP cry-REFL-2 dove | \glt He asked, “\textbf{Why} are you crying, dove?”

Knowledge Point: Interrogative pronouns are suffixed with the case markers corresponding to the questioned element~(\ref{Glo7:pasaruptin}), (\ref{Glo7:Traklamanchu}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Inti pasaruptin \textbf{imay urata} munayan? | \gll inti pasa-ru-pti-n imay ura-ta muna-ya-n | \gls sun pass-URGT-SUBDS-3 when hour-ACC want-PROG-3 | \glt \textbf{What time} will it be when the sun sets?
Content 2: \gsrc ¿Traklamanchu liyan? ¿\textbf{Piwan}yá? | \gll trakla-man-chu li-ya-n pi-wan-yá | \gls field-ALL-Q go-PROG-3 who-INSTR-EMPH | \glt Is he going to the field? \textbf{With whom}?

Knowledge Point: The enclitic generally attaches to the final word in the interrogative phrase: when the interrogative pronoun completes the phrase, it attaches directly to the interrogative; in contrast, when the phrase includes an NP, the enclitic attaches to the NP (\phono{pi-\pb{paq}-\pb{taq}} ‘for whom’ \phono{ima} \phono{qullqi-\pb{tr}} ‘what money’)~(\ref{Glo7:Chaypaqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Chaypaqa wiñaraptinqa, ¿\textbf{ayka} \textbf{puntrawnintataq} riganchik? | \gll chay-pa-qa wiña-ra-pti-n-qa ayka puntraw-ni-n-ta-taq riga-nchik | \gls DEM.D-LOC-TOP grow-UNINT-SUBDS-3-TOP how.many day-EUPH-3-ACC-SEQ irrigate-1PL | \glt When it grows, at \textbf{how many} days do you water it?

Knowledge Point: \phono{-kU} may indicate that the subject acts on himself/herself or that the subject of the verb is the object of the event referred to, i.e., \phono{-kU} derives verbs with the meanings ‘V one’s self’~(\ref{Glo7:Kikinpis}), (\ref{Glo7:Kundina}), and ‘be Ved’~(\ref{Glo7:nchik}), (\ref{Glo7:Pampa}). Note that \phono{-kU} is not restricted to forming reflexives and may also indicate pseudo-reflexives, middles, medio-passives and passives.
Content 1: \gsrc Kikinpis Campiona\textbf{ku}run. | \gll kiki-n-pis Campiona-ku-ru-n | \gls self-3-ADD poison.with.Campión-REFL-URGT-3 | \glt They themselves \textbf{Campioned themselves} [took Campion rat poison].
Content 2: \gsrc Kundina\textbf{ku}rushpa chay pashña kaqta trayaramun. | \gll kundina-ku-ru-shpa chay pashña ka-q-ta traya-ra-mu-n | \gls condemn-REFL-URGT-SUBIS DEM.D girl be-AG-ACC arrive-URGT-CISL-3 | \glt Condemning himself [turning into a zombie], he arrived at the girl’s place.
Content 3: \gsrc Mancha\textbf{ku}nchik runa wañuypaq kaptin. | \gll mancha-ku-nchik runa wañu-y-paq ka-pti-n | \gls scare-REFL-1PL person die-INF-PURP be-SUBDS-3 | \glt We \textbf{get scared} when people are about to die.
Content 4: \gsrc Pampa\textbf{ku}run chayshi. | \gll pampa-ku-ru-n chay-shi | \gls bury-REFL-URGT-3 DEM.D-EVR | \glt He \textbf{was buried}, they say.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-na} indicates that two or more actors act reflexively on each other, i.e., \phono{-na} derives verbs with the meaning ‘V each other’~(\ref{Glo7:Unayqa}), (\ref{Glo7:ValiPaqarin}).
Content 1: \gsrc Unayqa chay nishpa willa\textbf{naku}n. | \gll unay-qa chay ni-shpa willa-naku-n | \gls before-TOP DEM.D say-SUBIS tell-RECIP-3 | \glt Formerly, saying that, we told \textbf{each other}.
Content 2: \gsrc Vali\textbf{naku}:. ‘Paqarin yanapamay u paqarin ñuqakta chaypaq talpashun qampaktañataq’, ni\textbf{naku}:mi. | \gll vali-naku-: paqarin yanapa-ma-y u paqarin ñuqa-kta chay-paq talpa-shun qam-pa-kta-ña-taq ni-naku-:-mi | \gls solicit-RECIP-1 tomorrow help-1.OBJ-IMP or tomorrow I-ACC DEM.D-ABL plow-1PL.FUT you-GEN-ACC-DISC-SEQ say-RECIP-1-EVD | \glt We solicit \textbf{each other}, “Help me tomorrow,” or, “Tomorrow me and then we’ll plant yours,” we say to \textbf{each other}.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-na} is dependent and never appears independent of \phono{-kU}. \phono{-chinakU} derives verbs with the meaning ‘cause each other to V’~(\ref{Glo7:chinaku}), (\ref{Glo7:Kukankunata}).
Content 1: \gsrc Yuyari\textbf{chinaku}yan. | \gll yuya-ri-chi-naku-ya-n | \gls remember-INCEP-CAUS-RECIP-PROG-3 | \glt They’re \textbf{making} \textbf{each other} remember.
Content 2: \gsrc Kukankunata tragunkunata muyuyka\textbf{chinaku}shpa. | \gll kuka-n-kuna-ta tragu-n-kuna-ta muyu-yka-chi-naku-shpa | \gls coca-3-PL-ACC drink-3-PL-ACC circle-EXCEP-CAUS-RECIP-SUBIS | \glt \textbf{Making} their coca and liquor circulate \textbf{among themselves}.

Knowledge Point: This section partially repeats \sectref{ssec:copu} on equative verbs Please consult that section for further discussion and examples. \SYQ{} counts a single copulative verb, \phono{ka-}. Like the English verb \phono{be}, \phono{ka-} has both copulative~(\ref{Glo7:fwirti}), (\ref{Glo7:Qammi}) and existential~(\ref{Glo7:Kanna}), (\ref{Glo7:Rantiqpis}) interpretations. \phono{ka-} is irregular: its third person singular present tense form, \phono{ka-n}, never appears in equational statements, but only in existential statements. ‘This is a llama’ would be translated \phono{Kay-qa} \phono{llama-m}, while ‘There are llamas’ would be translated \phono{Llama-qa ka-n-mi}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ñuqa-nchik fwirti \textbf{ka}nchik patachita, matrkata, trakranchik lluqsiqta mikushpam. | \gll ñuqa-nchik fwirti ka-nchik patachi-ta matrka-ta trakra-nchik lluqsi-q-ta miku-shpa-m | \gls I-1PL strong be-1PL wheat.soup-ACC ground.cereal.meal-ACC field-1PL come.out-AG-ACC eat-SUBIS-EVD | \glt We \textbf{are} strong because we eat what comes out of our fields -- wheat soup and toasted grain.
Content 2: \gsrc Qammi salvasyunniy \textbf{ka}nki. | \gll qam-mi salvasyun-ni-y ka-nki | \gls you-EVD salvation-EUPH-1 be-2 | \glt You \textbf{are} my salvation.
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Kan}ña piña turu. | \gll ka-n-ña piña turu | \gls be-3-DISC angry bull | \glt \textbf{There are} mean bulls.
Content 4: \gsrc Rantiqpis \textbf{kan}taqmi. | \gll ranti-q-pis ka-n-taq-mi | \gls buy-AG-ADD be-3-SEQ-EVD | \glt \textbf{There are} also buyers.

Knowledge Point: Evidentials (\phono{-mI}, \phono{-shI} and \phono{-trI}) often attach to the predicate in equational statements without \phono{ka-n}~(\ref{Glo7:Vakay}), (\ref{Glo7:Llutan}).
Content 1: \gsrc Vakay wira wira\textbf{m} matraypi puñushpa, allin pastuta mikushpam. | \gll vaka-y wira wira-m matray-pi puñu-shpa allin pastu-ta miku-shpam | \gls cow-1 fat fat-EVD cave-LOC sleep-SUBIS good pasture.grass-ACC eat-SUBIS | \glt Sleeping in a cave and eating good pasture, my cow \textbf{is} really fat.
Content 2: \gsrc Llutan\textbf{shi}ki. | \gll llutan-sh-iki | \gls deformed-EVR-IKI | \glt \textbf{They are} deformed, they say.

Knowledge Point: The principal strategy in \SYQ{} for constructing equational statements is to employ the continuous form \phono{ka\pb{-ya}-n}~(\ref{Glo7:Alpakachu}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Alpakachu wak \textbf{kaya}n? | \gll alpaka-chu wak ka-ya-n | \gls alpaca-Q DEM.D be-PROG-3 | \glt \textbf{Is that} alpaca [wool]?

Knowledge Point: This section partially repeats \sectref{ssec:alloP} on possession. Please consult that section for further discussion and glossed examples. \SYQ{} employs the suffixes of the nominal paradigm to indicate possession. These are the same in all dialects for all persons except the first person singular. Two of the five dialects --~\AMV{} and \LT~-- follow the \QII{} pattern, marking the first person singular with \phono{-y}; three dialects --~\ACH, \CH, and \SP~-- follow the \QI{} pattern marking it with \phono{-:} (vowel length). The \SYQ{} nominal suffixes, then, are: \phono{-y} or \phono{-:} (1\lsc{p}), \phono{-Yki} (2\lsc{p}), \phono{-n} (3\lsc{p}), \phono{-nchik} (1\lsc{pl})~(\ref{Glo7:Wiqawni}--\ref{Glo7:Chayna}). Table~\ref{Tab10} displays this paradigm.
Content 1: \gsrc Wiqawni\textbf{y}mi nanan. | \gll wiqaw-ni-y-mi nana-n | \gls waist-EUPH-1-EVD hurt-3 | \glt \textbf{My} lower back hurts.
Content 2: \gsrc Chayna achka wambra\textbf{nchik}ta familya\textbf{nchik}kunata aparun. | \gll chayna achka wambra-nchik-ta familya-nchik-kuna-ta apa-ru-n | \gls thus a.lot child-1PL-ACC family-1PL-PL-ACC bring-URGT-3 | \glt So they took away lots of \textbf{our} children, our relatives.

Knowledge Point: In the case of words ending in a consonant, \phono{-ni} --~semantically vacuous~-- precedes the person suffix~(\ref{Glo7:Gana}).
Content 1: \gsrc Gana\textbf{wnin}ta qatikura qalay qalay. | \gll ganaw-ni-n-ta qati-ku-ra qalay qalay | \gls cattle-EUPH-3-ACC follow-REFL-PST all all | \glt They herded \textbf{their} cattle, absolutely all.

Knowledge Point: \SYQ{} “have” constructions are formed \lsc{substantive-poss} \phono{ka-}~(\ref{Glo7:wambrayki}).
Content 1: \gsrc Mana \textbf{wambrayki kan}chu mana \textbf{qariyki kan}chu. | \gll mana wambra-yki ka-n-chu mana qari-yki ka-n-chu | \gls no child-2 be-3-NEG no man-2 be-3-NEG | \glt \textbf{You} don’t \textbf{have children}, \textbf{you} don’t \textbf{have a husband}.

Knowledge Point: In case a noun or pronoun referring to the possessor appears in the same clause, the noun or pronoun is case-marked genitive with either \phono{-pa}, \phono{-pi}, or \phono{-paq}~(\ref{Glo7:wallqa}), (\ref{Glo7:Asnuqa}).\footnote{An anonymous reviewer points out that possessive constructions are formed differently in \QI{}: “The possessed item takes a possessive suffix and the copula takes -pU followed by an object suffix that agrees with the person of the possessor. In other words, the verbal object suffix and the possessive suffix refer to the same person.” The reviewer offers the following examples:
Content 1: \gsrc Duyñupa wallqa\textbf{n}ta ruwan. | \gll duyñu-pa wallqa-n-ta ruwa-n | \gls owner-GEN garland-3-ACC make-3 | \glt They make the owner \textbf{his} \phono{wallqa} (garland).
Content 2: \gsrc Asnuqa hatarishpash ripukun chay runa\textbf{pa} wasi\textbf{n}man. | \gll asnu-qa hatari-shpa-sh ripu-ku-n chay runa-pa wasi-n-man | \gls donkey-TOP get.up-SUBIS-EVR go-REFL-3 DEM.D person-GEN house-3-ALL | \glt Geting up, the donkey went to the man\textbf{’s} house.

Knowledge Point: In \SYQ, it is the evidentials, \phono{-mI}, \phono{-shI}, and \phono{-trI}, that, by virtue of their placement, indicate focus or comment. For example, in~(\ref{Glo7:Paqarin}), the evidential attaches to the direct object, \phono{shakash} ‘guinea pig’, and it is that element that is stressed: it is a \pb{guinea pig} that you are going to butcher tomorrow. In~(\ref{Glo7:qamqa}) the evidential attaches to the temporal noun \phono{paqarin} ‘tomorrow’, with the resulting interpretation: it is \pb{tomorrow} that you are going to butcher a guinea pig. Evidentials never attach to the topic or subject. Topic and subject are, rather, marked with \phono{-qa}, as is \phono{qam} in~(\ref{Glo7:Paqarin}) and~(\ref{Glo7:qamqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Paqarin qamqa shakashta\textbf{tr} wañuchinki.~\updag | \gll paqarin qam-qa shakash-ta-tr wañu-chi-nki | \gls tomorrow you-TOP guinea.pig-ACC-EVC die-CAUS-2 | \glt Tomorrow you’ll kill a \textbf{guinea pig}\tss{F}.
Content 2: \gsrc Paqarin\textbf{tri} qamqa shakashta wañuchinki.~\updag | \gll paqarin-tri qam-qa shakash-ta wañu-chi-nki | \gls tomorrow-EVC you-TOP guinea.pig-ACC die-CAUS-2 | \glt \textbf{Tomorrow}\tss{F} you’ll kill a guinea pig.
Content 3: \gsrc Paqarin qamqa shakashta\textbf{tr} wañuchinki.~\updag | \gll paqarin qam-qa shakash-ta-tr wañu-chi-nki | \gls tomorrow you-TOP guinea.pig-ACC-EVC die-CAUS-2 | \glt Tomorrow you’ll kill a \textbf{guinea pig}\tss{F}.
Content 4: \gsrc Paqarin\textbf{tri} qamqa shakashta wañuchinki.~\updag | \gll paqarin-tri qam-qa shakash-ta wañu-chi-nki | \gls tomorrow-EVC you-TOP guinea.pig-ACC die-CAUS-2 | \glt \textbf{Tomorrow}\tss{F} you’ll kill a guinea pig.

Knowledge Point: This section partially repeats \sectref{ssec:sdfv} on substantives derived from verbs Please consult that section for further discussion and glossed examples. \SYQ{} forms infinitive complements with \phono{-y}~(\ref{Glo7:Munankichu}--\ref{Glo7:Algunus}), purposive complements with \phono{-q}~(\ref{Glo7:Misa}), (\ref{Glo7:Pasaruptin}), indicative complements with \phono{-sHa}~(\ref{Glo7:Atipa}--\ref{Glo7:wambran}), and subjunctive complements with \phono{-na}~(\ref{Glo7:Puchukananta}). Infinitive complements often figure as the object of the verbs ~\phono{muna-} ‘want’~(\ref{Glo7:Munankichu}), \phono{atipa-} ‘be able’~(\ref{Glo7:Lukuyarun}), and \phono{gusta-} ‘like’~(\ref{Glo7:Algunus}). Indicative complements are common with the verbs \phono{yatra-} ‘know’~(\ref{Glo7:maypa}), (\ref{Glo7:Kwirpu}), \phono{qunqa-} ‘forget’, \phono{qawa} ‘see’~(\ref{Glo7:wambran}), and \phono{uyari-} ‘hear’. Note that infinitive complements are case-marked with accusative \phono{-ta} and that \phono{-q} purposive complements only occur with verbs of movement (\phono{-na-}(\lsc{poss})\phono{-paq}, being used for other verb types~(\ref{Glo7:pulluyki}) (see \sectref{sssc:con})).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Munankichu sintachi\textbf{y}\textbf{ta}qa? | \gll muna-nki-chu sintachi-y-ta-qa | \gls want-2-Q put.ribbons-INF-ACC-TOP | \glt Do you \textbf{want to}? To piece their ears with ribbons?
Content 2: \gsrc Algunus turuqa runa waqra\textbf{yta} \textbf{gusta}n. | \gll algunus turu-qa runa waqra-y-ta gusta-n | \gls some bull-TOP person horn-INF-ACC like-3 | \glt Some bulls \textbf{like to} gore people.
Content 3: \gsrc Misa lulaq \textbf{shamu}n. | \gll misa lula-q shamu-n | \gls mass make-AG come-3 | \glt They \textbf{come} to hold mass.
Content 4: \gsrc Pasaruptin qawa\textbf{q} \textbf{hamu}ni. | \gll pasa-ru-pti-n qawa-q hamu-ni | \gls pass-URGT-SUBDS-3 see-AG come-1 | \glt When that happened, I \textbf{came to see}.
Content 5: \gsrc Atipa\textbf{sa}ntatriki ruwan. | \gll atipa-sa-n-ta-tr-iki ruwa-n | \gls be.able-PRF-3-ACC-EVC-IKI make-3 | \glt They do \textbf{what they can}.
Content 6: \gsrc Ñuqaqa wambran \textbf{qipikusan}ta qawarqanichu. | \gll ñuqa-qa wambra-n qipi-ku-sa-n-ta qawa-rqa-ni-chu | \gls I-TOP child-3 carry-REFL-PRF-3-ACC see-PST-1-NEG | \glt I didn’t see \textbf{that she carried} her baby.
Content 7: \gsrc Puchuka\textbf{na}nta munani. | \gll puchuka-na-n-ta muna-ni | \gls finish-NMLZ-3-ACC want-1 | \glt I want \textbf{them to finish}.
Content 8: \gsrc ¿Munankichu sintachi\textbf{y}\textbf{ta}qa? | \gll muna-nki-chu sintachi-y-ta-qa | \gls want-2-Q put.ribbons-INF-ACC-TOP | \glt Do you \textbf{want to}? To piece their ears with ribbons?
Content 9: \gsrc Lukuyarun runalla. Manam puñu\textbf{yta} \textbf{atipa}rachu. | \gll luku-ya-ru-n runa-lla mana-m puñu-y-ta atipa-ra-chu | \gls crazy-INCH-URGT-3 person-RSTR no-EVD sleep-INF-ACC be.able-PST-NEG | \glt My husband was going crazy. He \textbf{couldn’t} sleep.
Content 10: \gsrc Algunus turuqa runa waqra\textbf{yta} \textbf{gusta}n. | \gll algunus turu-qa runa waqra-y-ta gusta-n | \gls some bull-TOP person horn-INF-ACC like-3 | \glt Some bulls \textbf{like to} gore people.

Knowledge Point: This section partially repeats \sectref{ssec:sdfv} on substantives derived from verbs. Please consult that section for further discussion and glossed examples. \SYQ{} forms relative clauses with the four deverbalizing suffixes: concretizing \phono{-na}~(\ref{Glo7:puntraw}), agentive \phono{-q}~(\ref{Glo7:Rigakuq}), perfective \phono{-sHa}~(\ref{Glo7:Nuqaqa}), and infinitive \phono{-y}~(\ref{Glo7:vilakuy}). As these structures are formally nouns, they are inflected with substantive suffixes, not verbal suffixes (\phono{ranti-sa-\pb{yki}} \phono{*ranti-sa-\pb{nki}} ‘that you sold’)~(\ref{Glo7:Rigalakullaq}).
Content 1: \gsrc Asta \textbf{wañukunay puntraw}kamatriki chayna purishaq. | \gll asta wañu-ku-na-y puntraw-kama-tr-iki chay-na puri-shaq | \gls until die-REFL-NMLZ-1 day-LIM-EVC-IKI thus walk-1.FUT | \glt Until \textbf{the day I die}, I’m going to walk around like that.
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Rigakuq luna} trabahaya:. | \gll riga-ku-q luna trabaha-ya-: | \gls irrigate-REFL-AG person work-PROG-1 | \glt \textbf{The people who water}, we’re working.
Content 3: \gsrc Ñuqaqa manam rimayta yatrara:chu prufusurni: nima\textbf{sa}nta. | \gll ñuqa-qa mana-m rima-y-ta yatra-ra-:-chu prufusur-ni-: ni-ma-sa-n-ta | \gls I-TOP no-EVD talk-INF-ACC know-PST-1-NEG teacher-EUPH-1 say-1.OBJ-PRF-3-ACC | \glt I didn’t know how to say \textbf{what my teacher said to me}.
Content 4: \gsrc Chay \textbf{vilakuy puntraw} simintiryupa. | \gll chay vila-ku-y puntraw simintiryu-pa | \gls DEM.D candle-REFL-INF day cemetery-LOC | \glt The \textbf{day we lit candles} in the cemetery.
Content 5: \gsrc Rigalakullaq ka: \textbf{mana rantikusa:taqa}. | \gll rigala-ku-lla-q ka-: mana ranti-ku-sa-:-ta-qa | \gls give.as.a.gift-REFL-RSTR-AG be-1 no buy-REFL-PRF-1-ACC-TOP | \glt I used to give away \textbf{what I didn’t sell}.

Knowledge Point: The inflected forms may be reinforced with possessive pronouns~(\ref{Glo7:rantikurasa}). \phono{-sHa} may additionally form nouns referring to the location where~(\ref{Glo7:fwirapi} or time at which~(\ref{Glo7:Urqupa}) an event \lsc{E} occurred. \phono{-sHa} is realized as \phono{-sa} in \ACH{}~(\ref{Glo7:Rigalakullaq}), \AMV{}~(\ref{Glo7:Pampaykuni}) and \SP{}~(\ref{Glo7:mayman}) and as \phono{-sha} in \LT{}~(\ref{Glo7:Kalamina}) and \CH. Any substantive constituent --~subject~(\ref{Glo7:Rigakuq}), object~(\ref{Glo7:Pampaykuni}), or complement~(\ref{Glo7:puntraw})~-- can be relativized. Nominalizing suffixes attach directly to the verb stem, with the exception that the person suffixes \phono{-wa/-ma} (first person object) and \phono{-sHu} (second person object) may intercede~(\ref{Glo7:Ampullakta}),~(\ref{Glo7:Filupa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Qampa \textbf{rantikurasa}ykiyá chay shakash. | \gll qam-pa ranti-ku-ra-sa-yki-yá chay shakash | \gls you-GEN buy-REFL-UNINT-PRF-2-EMPH DEM.D guinea.pig | \glt That guinea pig \textbf{that you sold}.
Content 2: \gsrc Chay fwirapi chay vilakuna rantiku\textbf{sa}n. | \gll chay fwira-pi chay vila-kuna ranti-ku-sa-n | \gls DEM.D outside-LOC DEM.D candle-PL buy-REFL-PRF-3 | \glt That’s outside \textbf{where they sell} candles.

Content 10: \gsrc Asta \textbf{wañukunay puntraw}kamatriki chayna purishaq. | \gll asta wañu-ku-na-y puntraw-kama-tr-iki chay-na puri-shaq | \gls until die-REFL-NMLZ-1 day-LIM-EVC-IKI thus walk-1.FUT | \glt Until \textbf{the day I die}, I’m going to walk around like that.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-pti} is employed when the subjects of the main and subordinate clauses are different (\phono{huk} \phono{qawa-\pb{pti-n-qa}}, \phono{ñuqa-nchik} \phono{qawa-nchik-chu} ‘Although others see, we don’t see’)~(\ref{Glo7:Qawayku}); \phono{shpa} and \phono{-shtin} are employed when the subjects of the two clauses are identical (\phono{tushu\pb{-shpa}} \phono{wasi-ta} \phono{kuti-mu-n} ‘Dancing they return home’) (\ref{Glo7:Chitchityaku}), (\ref{Glo7:Yantakunata}). \phono{-pti} generally indicates that the event of the subordinated clause began prior to that of the main clause but may also be employed in the case those events are simultaneous (\phono{urkista-qa} \phono{traya-mu\pb{-pti}-n} \phono{tushu-rqa-nchik} ‘When the band arrived, we dansed’).
Content 1: \gsrc Qawayku\textbf{ptin}qa sakristan wañurusa. | \gll qawa-yku-pti-n-qa sakristan wañu-ru-sa | \gls see-EXCEP-SUBDS-3-TOP sacristan die-URGT-NPST | \glt \textbf{When} \textbf{he} looked, the care-taker had died.
Content 2: \gsrc Chitchityaku\textbf{shpa} rikullan kabrakunaqa. | \gll chitchitya-ku-shpa riku-lla-n kabra-kuna-qa | \gls say.chit.chit-REFL-SUBIS go-RSTR-3 goat-PL-TOP | \glt “\textbf{Chit-chitting},” the goats just left.
Content 3: \gsrc Yantakunata qutu\textbf{shtin} lliptakunata kañaku\textbf{shtin}, hanay~\dots | \gll yanta-kuna-ta qutu-shtin llipta-kuna-ta kaña-ku-shtin hanay | \gls firewood-PL-ACC gather-SUBAVD ash-PL-ACC burn-REFL-SUBADV up.hill | \glt \textbf{Gathering} wood, \textbf{burning} ash, [we lived] up hill.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-shpa} generally indicates that the event of the subordinated clause is simultaneous with that of the main clause (\phono{sapu-qa} \phono{kurrkurrya-\pb{shpa}} \phono{kurri-ya-n} ‘The frog is running going kurr-kurr!’)~(\ref{Glo7:Traguwan}) but may also be employed in case the subordinated event precedes the main-clause event~(\ref{Glo7:Familyanchikta}).
Content 1: \gsrc Traguwan, kukawan tushuchi\textbf{shpa}llam kusichakuni. | \gll tragu-wan kuka-wan tushu-chi-shpa-lla-m kusicha-ku-ni | \gls drink-INSTR coca-INSTR dance-CAUS-SUBIS-RSTR-EVD harvest-REFL-1 | \glt With liquor and coca, \textbf{making} them dance, I harvest.
Content 2: \gsrc Familyanchikta wañurichi\textbf{shpa}qa lliw partiyan. | \gll familya-nchik-ta wañu-ri-chi-shpa-qa lliw parti-ya-n | \gls family-1PL-ACC die-INCEP-CAUS-SUBIS-TOP all distribute-PROG-3 | \glt \textbf{After} they killed our relatives, they distributed everything.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-shtin} is employed only when the main and subordinate clause events are simultaneous (\phono{Awa\pb{-shtin}} \phono{miku-chi-ni} \phono{wambra-y-ta} ‘(By) weaving, I feed my children’)~(\ref{Glo7:Yatrakunchik}).
Content 1: \gsrc Yatrakunchik imaynapis maski waqaku\textbf{shtin}pis~\dots{} asiku\textbf{shtin}pis~\dots{} imaynapis. | \gll yatra-ku-nchik imayna-pis maski waqa-ku-shtin-pis asi-ku-shtin-pis imayna-pis | \gls live-REFL-1PL how-ADD maski cry-REFL-SUBADV-ADD laugh-REFL-SUBIS-ADD how-ADD | \glt We live however we can, although \textbf{we’re crying}~\dots{} \textbf{laughing}~\dots{} however we can.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-pti} subordinates are suffixed with allocation suffixes (\phono{tarpu\pb{-pti}-\pb{nchik}} ‘when we plant’)~(\ref{Glo7:Manampaga}); \phono{-shpa} and \phono{-shtin} subordinates do not inflect for person or number (\phononb{*tarpu-\pb{shpa}-\pb{nchik}}; \phono{*tarpu-\pb{shtin}-\pb{yki}}). Subordinate verbs inherit tense, aspect and conditionality specification from the main clause verb (\phono{Ri-shpa qawa-\pb{y-man}} \phono{\pb{karqa}} ‘If I \pb{would have} gone, I \pb{would have} seen’).
Content 1: \gsrc Manam pagawa\textbf{ptiki}qa manam wambraykiqa alliyanqachu. | \gll mana-m paga-wa-pti-ki-qa mana-m wambra-yki-qa alli-ya-nqa-chu | \gls no-EVD pay-1.OBJ-SUBDS-2-TOP no-EVD child-2-TOP good-INCH-3.FUT-NEG | \glt \textbf{If} \textbf{you} don’t pay \textbf{me}, your son isn’t going to get better.

Knowledge Point: Depending on the context, \phono{-pti} and \phono{-shpa} can be translated by ‘when’~(\ref{Glo7:Qawayku}), ‘if’~(\ref{Glo7:Kuti}), ‘because’~(\ref{Glo7:Priykupaw}),~(\ref{Glo7:Payqa}) ‘although’~(\ref{Glo7:Qullqita}) or with a gerund~(\ref{Glo7:Chitchityaku}). \phono{-shtin} is translated by a gerund only~(\ref{Glo7:Yantakunata}),~(\ref{Glo7:Yatrakunchik}).
Content 1: \gsrc Qawayku\textbf{ptin}qa sakristan wañurusa. | \gll qawa-yku-pti-n-qa sakristan wañu-ru-sa | \gls see-EXCEP-SUBDS-3-TOP sacristan die-URGT-NPST | \glt \textbf{When} \textbf{he} looked, the care-taker had died.
Content 2: \gsrc Kuti\textbf{shpa}qa kutimushaq kimsa tawa watata. | \gll kuti-shpa-qa kuti-mu-shaq kimsa tawa wata-ta | \gls return-SUBIS-TOP return-CISL-1.FUT three four year-ACC | \glt \textbf{If} \textbf{I} come back, \textbf{I}’ll come back in three or four years.
Content 3: \gsrc Priykupaw puriyan siyrtumpatr warmin mal ka\textbf{pti}n. | \gll priykupaw puri-ya-n siyrtumpa-tr warmi-n mal ka-pti-n | \gls worried walk-PROG-3 certainly-EVC woman.3 bad be-SUBDS-3 | \glt Certainly, he’d be wandering around worried \textbf{because} \textbf{his wife} is sick.
Content 4: \gsrc Payqa rikunñash warmin saqiru\textbf{ptin}. | \gll pay-qa ri-ku-n-ña-sh warmi-n saqi-ru-pti-n | \gls he-TOP go-REFL-3-DISC-EVR woman-3 leave-URGT-SUBDS-3 | \glt He left \textbf{because} his wife abandoned him, they say.
Content 5: \gsrc Qullqita gana\textbf{shpa}\textbf{s} bankuman ima trurakunki | \gll qullqi-ta gana-shpa-s banku-man ima trura-ku-nki | \gls money-ACC earn-SUBIS-ADD bank-ALL what put-REFL-2 | \glt \textbf{Although} you earn money and save it in the bank
Content 6: \gsrc Chitchityaku\textbf{shpa} rikullan kabrakunaqa. | \gll chitchitya-ku-shpa riku-lla-n kabra-kuna-qa | \gls say.chit.chit-REFL-SUBIS go-RSTR-3 goat-PL-TOP | \glt “\textbf{Chit-chitting},” the goats just left.
Content 7: \gsrc Yantakunata qutu\textbf{shtin} lliptakunata kañaku\textbf{shtin}, hanay~\dots | \gll yanta-kuna-ta qutu-shtin llipta-kuna-ta kaña-ku-shtin hanay | \gls firewood-PL-ACC gather-SUBAVD ash-PL-ACC burn-REFL-SUBADV up.hill | \glt \textbf{Gathering} wood, \textbf{burning} ash, [we lived] up hill.
Content 8: \gsrc Yatrakunchik imaynapis maski waqaku\textbf{shtin}pis~\dots{} asiku\textbf{shtin}pis~\dots{} imaynapis. | \gll yatra-ku-nchik imayna-pis maski waqa-ku-shtin-pis asi-ku-shtin-pis imayna-pis | \gls live-REFL-1PL how-ADD maski cry-REFL-SUBADV-ADD laugh-REFL-SUBIS-ADD how-ADD | \glt We live however we can, although \textbf{we’re crying}~\dots{} \textbf{laughing}~\dots{} however we can.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-na-}\lsc{poss}\phono{-kama} is limitative. It forms subordinate clauses indicating that the event referred to either is simultaneous with~(\ref{Glo7:Mana}) or limits~(\ref{Glo7:Traki}) the event referred to in the main clause (\phono{puñu-\pb{na-y-kama}} ‘while I was sleeping’; \phono{wañu-\pb{na-n-kama}} ‘until she died’).
Content 1: \gsrc Mana vilakuranichu puñu\textbf{naykaman}. | \gll mana vila-ku-ra-ni-chu puñu-na-y-kaman | \gls no watch.over-REFL-PST-1-NEG sleep-NMLZ-1-LIM | \glt I didn’t keep watch \textbf{while} I was sleeping.
Content 2: \gsrc Traki paltanchikpis pushllu\textbf{nankama} purinchik. | \gll traki palta-nchik-pis pushllu-na-n-kama puri-nchik | \gls foot soul-1PL-ADD blister-NMLZ-3-LIM walk-1PL | \glt We walked \textbf{until} blisters formed on the souls of our feet.
